9252BB7F54274170AA3C360A0268F3FB.description: create media texts for a wide variety of audiences and purposes, and explain their content and design decisions (e.g., create a T-shirt logo and slogan for a school-wide information campaign; compile a collection of symbols found in traditional and contemporary art forms of specific Aboriginal groups)

61E3F178B6CF49D3810EB99D26210B0B.description: compare a variety of media texts, and evaluate them for balance, inclusiveness, and possible bias (e.g., media texts representing people of different ages, genders, income levels, and ethnocultural backgrounds; news reports of a conflict that present single or multiple points of view)

04395102692140E781B1B5B00605A9BA.description: view, read, and listen to media texts, and identify strategies used in them to influence specific audiences (e.g., youth-oriented music, celebrity endorsements, visual images)

9DAA575D55BA4536BF962B92F7ACFDE3.description: Developing Media Knowledge and Skills: demonstrate an understanding of, interpret, and create a variety of media texts.

3A1A37DC70054E63AD0D1C76D138BF15.description: identify and explain the purpose of a wide variety of school and community resources that are available to support lifelong learning, and use them appropriately to implement their educational and career plans (e.g., Independent Learning Centre, career counselling centres, the Ontario Skills Passport, cooperative education and apprenticeship opportunities, postsecondary education guides)

20E760A2D0984AF1AE34678F672F3145.description: participate and interact effectively, and take on leadership responsibilities to complete collaborative classroom projects (e.g., listen actively; clarify directions; share ideas; plan work and delegate tasks; offer constructive criticism)

57137B198ABA4E1396888671C2EDB582.description: use a wide variety of study and timemanagement skills effectively to carry out learning tasks, and explain their relevance to future academic and career plans (e.g., manage time efficiently; plan work and complete tasks satisfactorily; use technology appropriately)

C275347E01484A08ADD9A0C6EA5BB0CB.description: describe graduation requirements of the Ontario secondary school system and support services that are available to help them achieve their goals (e.g., graduation requirements and related components, such as compulsory credit, transcript, full-disclosure requirements, the literacy test, diploma requirements for community involvement activities, the Specialist High-Skills Major program, criteria for earning a diploma or certificate of achievement; services to assist with planning and goal-setting for postsecondary life)

DC534FA05ECC40DE9B6844522D022CA5.description: Adapting to School Life in Ontario: demonstrate knowledge of and adaptation to the Ontario education system;

C1F2E78AA5E049E59E367A21687FFCB0.description: describe some benefits and challenges of living in a society composed of diverse linguistic and cultural groups (e.g., the effects of maintaining or not maintaining particular forms of dress in certain cultures; the effects of accommodating or not accommodating various religious practices or traditions at school and work)

289B9F7A3B6448429EB174549CB5B913.description: demonstrate knowledge of important social and political documents that guarantee rights and freedoms in Canadian society (e.g., identify the basic rights specified in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the Ontario Human Rights Code, school board equity policies)

9E064BD6A15F44AF95D64EED0F172CAD.description: demonstrate knowledge of a variety of significant facts about Canadian history and culture (e.g., identify contributions of Aboriginal individuals to Canada; describe the early settlement patterns and contributions of significant groups and individuals in New France and in British North America)

195DFB6B6F11428B90A5BF6A969C390D.description: Developing Awareness of Canada, Citizenship, and Diversity: demonstrate an understanding of the rights and responsibilities of Canadian citizenship, and of the contributions of diverse groups to Canadian society;

805EDD55FC934E0085EC6FAFE818BE8C.description: identify non-verbal communication cues that are appropriate or inappropriate in a wide variety of social, academic, and workplace situations, and adjust their behaviour to suit the particular occasion (e.g., role play scenarios requiring formal and informal behaviour, and determine what behaviour is appropriate in each case)

F722553CCFFA4046821AE264143B71BF.description: determine and use the appropriate language register in a wide variety of social, classroom, and workplace contexts (e.g., “Huh?” to peers versus “I don’t understand” to a teacher; “Joe” to a co-worker versus “Mr. Baca” to a customer or supervisor; “May I speak to / I’d like to speak to Ms. Starsky” when phoning for an employment interview versus “Is Sabina there?” when phoning a friend; “Okay, guys” when addressing a class project team versus “My fellow students” when giving a campaign speech for election to the Student Council)

9213EDB12F8148ABBE8FE5D94E8CE998.description: Using English in Socially and Culturally Appropriate Ways: use English and non-verbal communication strategies appropriately in a variety of social contexts;

51A17513E16F4182BDC9E7441EA81FEE.description: select and use a wide variety of writing strategies before, during, and after writing, and reflect after writing on the strategies they found most helpful (e.g., use a reflection journal to explain thinking and identify strengths, areas for improvement, and next steps; respond to teacher and peer questions about why they used certain strategies more often than others)

2821B7C940D948218678C0A5B9B113CB.description: use a wide variety of elements of effective presentation to publish a final product (e.g., a cast list and drama dialogue format for a play, a table of contents for a handbook or manual, a brief glossary of terms for an essay about new technology, computer-generated graphs and charts for a science report)

E2AFB36B35E649F1B91082C0D88E4AD9.description: revise, edit, and proofread drafts using a wide variety of strategies (e.g., reread for clarity and organization of ideas; use print and electronic resources to confirm spelling; vary word choice through the use of a thesaurus; review drafts with the teacher and peers, and explain how a piece of writing has evolved)

DA719E82984F41C8B15B67EF1C5C0E15.description: produce draft pieces of writing using a wide variety of strategies and models (e.g., a variety of graphic organizers, jot-notes made while reading, student exemplars or authentic texts)

965ABC7E83BE4A0C9FC82141B364FAE1.description: use a wide variety of pre-writing strategies to generate vocabulary and develop and organize ideas for writing (e.g., consider purpose and audience in choosing a form for writing; generate ideas using webs, discussions with peers and the teacher, and prior reading and experience; cluster and sort ideas and information; consult the teacherlibrarian about relevant print and electronic resource materials)

5698849EC8974D9BA54BD695D6280199.description: Using the Writing Process: use the stages of the writing process.

7072368405EF48089780CD499B0BBEB6.description: use a wide variety of spelling strategies to spell words accurately (e.g., divide words into syllables; consult specialized print and electronic dictionaries; use electronic spell-checkers; record difficult words in a spelling list or journal, highlighting tricky letters or groups of letters)

45E38D5ABD814DD6ADE67689E4A38748.description: use correctly the grammatical structures and print conventions of written English appropriate for this level

FC297783E1FC4D029707FF8965F98F36.description: Developing Accuracy in Writing: use correctly the conventions of written English appropriate for this level, including grammar, usage, spelling, and punctuation;

154A49E429C54172BC3DD3AD8731B369.description: use a wide variety of connecting devices and transition words and phrases to show relationships between ideas in linked sentences and paragraphs (e.g., now that, as a result of, because of, although, even though)

E092C73B2511403CA8D806BB1A181C51.description: organize information to develop a central idea in a structured composition of three or more paragraphs (e.g., use a graphic organizer to map cause-and-effect relationships for a report about an endangered species; use the five-W’s format in a newspaper article about a real or imaginary community event)

41E539B32E47495BA9E1600FA5B9F7D0.description: Organizing Ideas in Writing: organize ideas coherently in writing

A0641B769DB744D39C6AB4D0357894B9.description: write longer and more complex texts to communicate information for official and personal purposes using a wide variety of forms (e.g., a résumé and cover letter; an online purchase agreement; a letter of complaint to a customer service department; a letter to cancel a contract, service, or subscription)

65AEF83933064D3CBB09782698D68F6C.description: write longer and more complex texts to express ideas and feelings using a wide variety of forms (e.g., poems, song lyrics/raps, blogs, e-mails or letters, narratives, descriptions, journal entries)

413C50FD1EB84488868B06AB3205686A.description: write longer and more complex texts to convey information and ideas for academic purposes using a wide variety of forms (e.g., a series of linked paragraphs synthesizing information from an independent research project about the changing role of technology; a news report using the five-W’s format; a mystery story using the structures and conventions of the genre; a report outlining the steps in a science experiment)

A286E739C4D14894A4C41A3E254713E2.description: Writing for Different Purposes: write in a variety of forms for different purposes and audiences;

F1EA67F3617D437A8B83D41A3D9D8876.description: compare a wide variety of sources of information to evaluate their reliability (e.g., websites, newspapers, tabloids, blogs)

BA2CBDA8E51E49A081935264D85872A6.description: select information and organize it effectively for a wide variety of purposes (e.g., use a graphic organizer to identify the basic rights in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms; compare cultural practices of diverse groups using a T-chart or Venn diagram)

8430BD593EF840FF88B16CFF26C45DEB.description: locate and compare information for independent research from a variety of school and community sources selected in collaboration with the teacher-librarian, and cite information from those sources appropriately (e.g., articles, non-fiction books, encyclopaedias, websites, DVDs, blogs)

3B12E5CEAA6F491A967FBB474CC63972.description: Developing Research Skills: locate and extract relevant information from written and graphic texts for a variety of purposes.

1D2199C94ACE451F96FF48418F399BC1.description: use a wide variety of resources to extend vocabulary and determine the precise meaning of words (e.g., select among a range of vocabulary resources, such as dictionaries, glossaries, manuals, online references, and technical dictionaries)

29FDB80938E74F7697447A81211F2451.description: use knowledge of a variety of patterns of word structure and derivation to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words (e.g., recognize changes of meaning caused by suffixes that differentiate parts of speech [photograph, photographer, photographic]; recognize root words with Latin and Greek origins used in science, mathematics, and technology [milli = thousand: millimetre = a thousandth of a metre; micro = small: microscope = an optical instrument for viewing very small objects])

2B2A731B96B9487D85FD81E85535618B.description: use a wide variety of vocabulary acquisition strategies to build subject-specific vocabulary and determine the meaning of unfamiliar words (e.g., compare multiple definitions found in a dictionary and select the correct meaning for a particular context; compile subject-specific glossaries; create lists of synonyms)

240F049D6F044F8C9C5432B4B8DE4447.description: Developing Vocabulary: use a variety of strategies to build vocabulary;

3F13C4E1A9794A67980846DB4FEEFAD9.description: demonstrate an understanding of the grammatical structures of English and conventions of print used in texts appropriate for this level

CCD03F494E7F42B3B4C3D774C41B5E4E.description: identify a wide variety of connecting devices and transition words and phrases, and explain how they show relationships among ideas in texts (e.g., either … or, neither … nor, both … and, as … as, although, as a result of

02F80EA0B30E45CB8B61484A02202989.description: use specific features of a wide variety of texts to locate information and aid comprehension (e.g., graphics, questions, summaries, footnotes/ endnotes, reference lists/ works cited, back covers of novels)

A4DA13D957524BF68933F7DF7EDC2817.description: confirm and extend understanding of texts after they have read them (e.g., do further research to deepen understanding of a topic; identify bias; participate in school reading clubs)

FC830B7174C048F5B65C2D0C241A8195.description: familiarize themselves with texts before they read them (e.g., independently generate a list of questions about the topic; brainstorm the topic with a partner to activate prior knowledge; preview text features to understand organization) • understand texts while they are reading them (e.g., interpret context clues; use visualization to clarify details of characters, scenes, or concepts; monitor understanding by identifying and restating the main idea and supporting details; summarize sections of text during reading; make inferences about a character’s motivation)

875C808E1C3C4C79AD8CCDAC396C972A.description: Using Reading Comprehension Strategies: use a variety of reading strategies throughout the reading process to extract meaning from texts;

E0CD69ACF657408BB42B661DD8D303CA.description: identify a wide variety of literary elements in short stories, novels, and poems, and explain how they help convey the author’s meaning (e.g., explain why they think an author uses a first-person or a third-person narrator; explain how setting, plot, and character help illustrate the theme in a short story)

22E55A366EF24CCAA69B564400977DB0.description: analyse a wide variety of text forms to identify key characteristics, and explain how they help to communicate meaning (e.g., illustrations in a “how-to” manual help clarify instructions; captions in photo essays clarify or highlight the message of the pictures; numbered points in an overview or summary identify key information) Teacher prompt: “How does the organizational pattern in this manual make it easy for you to locate the information you need?”

AB540AA1F3A54F82944F99E66DA1B8D6.description: respond to more complex texts in a variety of ways (e.g., identify what is fact and what is opinion in newspaper, online, or magazine articles; explain what they would change in an author’s treatment of a particular topic; identify a favourite passage in a text and explain what they like about it)

7EA8C67DA60C4370BB3E4E2763FA7DC1.description: demonstrate an understanding of complex texts in a wide variety of ways (e.g., follow a series of instructions to set up a DVD player; summarize a report about the impact of human activity on aquatic systems; describe how they would “counsel” a character in a novel)

2BC932D856EF45C8A5428597748EE40A.description: read a wide variety of increasingly complex texts (e.g., novels, magazine articles, manuals, online and print encyclopaedias, textbook excerpts, informational books on a range of topics)

B811C2A6B924497792BA23F2285C1745.description: Reading for Meaning: read and demonstrate understanding of a variety of texts for different purposes;

238406A0DE3D4B0184C50C7EF76F0C7F.description: use a wide variety of oral communication strategies to bridge gaps in spoken communication (e.g., notice and correct slips and errors; anticipate misunderstandings and rephrase to avoid or correct them; use circumlocution and paraphrase to compensate for incomplete knowledge of vocabulary and grammar)

716D11EBF4B04723B3840A1B8E8F9EBC.description: use appropriately a wide variety of pronunciation, stress, rhythm, and intonation patterns of spoken English to communicate both explicit and implicit meaning accurately (e.g., stress the content words in a sentence to clarify meaning [I read the book last night]; use pitch and volume appropriately to indicate emphasis and /or emotions [surprise, joy, annoyance]; use tone and volume to clarify implied messages in rap lyrics)

DEDC392000284A938CE385A25386F117.description: use correctly the grammatical structures of spoken English appropriate for this level

B7415B0DC5F249B59415E7C0301171D2.description: Developing Accuracy in Speaking: use correctly the language structures appropriate for this level to communicate orally in English

0B9C0B37F4284879922AEA4A30EF0D23.description: present ideas and information orally for academic purposes in a wide variety of situations (e.g., make a presentation on the rights and responsibilities of Canadian citizenship, with reference to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms; interview an expert or an eyewitness in preparation for writing a news article)

3BCB0940954A43CEA3C8875E22345434.description: use a wide variety of conversational expressions to negotiate spoken interactions of many different types (e.g., accept and reject information using expressions such as “I thought so”, “I knew it”, “I don’t see it that way”, “I’m not sure about that”; close a formal conversation or job interview using expressions such as “Thank you for your time”, “I really appreciate ...”)

4A9B906F8C5C4E2498B4AF19C23555CB.description: engage in extended spoken interactions on a variety of topics and in a variety of situations (e.g., work in a group to plan and organize a class trip, to dramatize events from stories and novels studied in class, and/or to negotiate solutions to tasks and problems)

A5167FCCA40F4A828C969DC6080ABBCB.description: Developing Fluency in Speaking: use speaking skills and strategies to communicate in English for a variety of classroom and social purposes;

DA2BE81D626E416685EA1F786681D55E.description: demonstrate understanding of spoken English on a wide variety of topics in interactive situations (e.g., in a collaborative activity to develop a group presentation; in discussions with peers about current events or issues)

D638A72C483942A1807F26842340BE84.description: demonstrate comprehension of specific information in complex directions, instructions, and classroom presentations (e.g., take notes on a documentary; use information from a classroom presentation to complete a graphic organizer; identify differences between reports of a news event from radio and television broadcasts; follow a series of technical instructions to complete a task)

0D7B0D41DA574F8E8CC447B85193FF31.description: Developing Listening Comprehension: demonstrate the ability to understand, interpret, and evaluate spoken English for a variety of purposes
